name: Self-sufficient builds (moved from High magic worlds)
author: Agadris

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Perhaps, not the right topic to write this in but I hardly see any point in starting another one because it might not spur a full-on discussion...

Guys, what build do you consider to be the most self-sufficient? I mean, what is, in your opinion, the strongest build capable of survival and dealing with nearly everything that comes its way without any need for magic items, scrolls and any gear other than mundane one? To make it even more challenging, let's say that the build also shouldn't rely on self-buffing.

I mean, sure, at some point the environment can get so harsh that it becomes impossible to survive in it without a proper gear and magic tools. But we are talking about the build that can do relatively well, with all the abovementioned limitations, there where others are bound to fail by default.

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content: This question comes from a minor obsession with the idea that in case of a truly powerful build its power is intrinsic to it. I know that any game design strives to prevent anything of the kind from existing because otherwise there would be too little space for variety and that would make the game boring but still...

posts.author: Orion
posts.content: Dragon Shape form, Druid / Monk / XXX with BAB 26+

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Yep... I totally expected something with Monk mojo to show up immediately. And if we don't consider Dragon Shape to be self-buffing, I agree with you, Orion, that the suggested combo would probably make the most efficient non-gear-dependent and well-protected-on-every-front build. 

I wonder if somebody can come up with something else, though.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Iron Golem Form (Shapechange Spell), Druid / Monk / XXX with BAB 26+

*slapped by Agadris*

Edit:
This is stronger: yip-yip-you-re-dead-druid-6-shifter-7-a ... tml#p13992

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Yes, Dragonshape, even without any buffs at all - up to medium-high modules/PW's is pretty strong.
If we are talking about pure muscle, I also bet on a well-build Dwarven Defender.
The third option, the do-it-all Ftr/Rog/CoT with its incredible saves & versatility & trap skills, OR its brother Ftr/Wm/CoT in an EDR III set-up.
And I'm gonna throw another one, as an outsider, but it works remarkably well, a Ranger(29)/SD(1)/CoT(10).
Possibly others too, depending on how well they have been built.

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Nah... no slapping , Orion After all, druid's powers are intrinsic to the class and cannot be dispelled so they hardly can be called self-buffing in full sense of that word.

Ninjad by Valerfor but posting anyway.

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote:Yes, Dragonshape, even without any buffs at all - up to medium-high modules/PW's is pretty strong.
If we are talking about pure muscle, I also bet on a well-build Dwarven Defender.
The third option, the do-it-all Ftr/Rog/CoT with its incredible saves & versatility & trap skills, OR its brother Ftr/Wm/CoT in an EDR III set-up.
And I'm gonna throw another one, as an outsider, but it works remarkably well, a Ranger(29)/SD(1)/CoT(10).
Possibly others too, depending on how well they have been built.
Now we are talking... these seem to be nice go-to combos if you are planning an 'itemless' playthrough of some major modules or playing on low-magic (perhaps, even mid-magic, correct me if I'm wrong) servers.
Btw, is it a sound idea to build a Barb/Rogue/CoT dexer with ED that uses Barb's Rage/Greater Rage to boost STR to deal more damage to the sneak-crit-proof opponents; CoT is conceived for its boost to saves (though in this case that would be a minor boost, I guess)?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Here's another contender...

Epic Brawler Champion

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Agadris wrote:
Valerfor wrote:Yes, Dragonshape, even without any buffs at all - up to medium-high modules/PW's is pretty strong.
If we are talking about pure muscle, I also bet on a well-build Dwarven Defender.
The third option, the do-it-all Ftr/Rog/CoT with its incredible saves &amp; versatility &amp; trap skills, OR its brother Ftr/Wm/CoT in an EDR III set-up.
And I'm gonna throw another one, as an outsider, but it works remarkably well, a Ranger(29)/SD(1)/CoT(10).
Possibly others too, depending on how well they have been built.
Now we are talking... these seem to be nice go-to combos if you are planning an 'itemless' playthrough of some major modules or playing on low-magic (perhaps, even mid-magic, correct me if I'm wrong) servers.
Btw, is it a sound idea to build a Barb/Rogue/CoT dexer with ED that uses Barb's Rage/Greater Rage to boost STR to deal more damage to the sneak-crit-proof opponents; CoT is conceived for its boost to saves (though in this case that would be a minor boost, I guess)?
Your only problems are going to be the split and the starting stats. You're going to need at least 13 levels of Rogue for ED, lots of Barbarian if you want to rage a lot (15 levels will only give you 4 Greater Rages), and probably at least 10 levels of CoT (not just for the saves - the bonus feats will be very useful). Obviously you'll be wanting plenty of Dex, but you'll also need lots of Con if you want Rage to last longer than a burp.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Barb, might be pushing it a little Agadris, I would feel more comfortable when having an additional source of dmg, like EWS.

Your only problems are going to be the split and the starting stats. posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote:Barb, might be pushing it a little Agadris, I would feel more comfortable when having an additional source of dmg, like EWS.
Okay... hence the Ftr in the combos you suggested, Valerfor. I see. 
Btw, this 'Ftr/Wm/CoT in an EDR III set-up' and this 'Ranger(29)/SD(1)/CoT(10)' sound very interesting. Are there any such builds on the forum?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Dwarven Master Slicer => http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/buil ... 24576.html#
For the second one, I would have make it myself probably, but I know from the class-split & the available feats that it will be a really flexible build with lots of skills, traps, full tumble, solid saving throws, HiPS, BoE, etc.
Hm, that one, however, would definitely be a level-forty build (because the SD-level, should come at 37, for maximum efficiency),
Better would be, Ranger(30)-SD(2)-CoT(8) OR Ranger(30)-SD(2)-Ftr(8), a more offensive variant of the first but with lesser saving throws.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I just remembered another nice Ranger build, with HS instead, by Mick.
Minsc => minsc-and-other-bg-characters-t2354360.html#p6048

Ranger is a very underrated class IMO.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
This part of the thread has evolved into its own topic and derailed the original thread so I moved it over here.
Mick

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Agadris, I wonder why you will exclude self buffers when you ask for a versatile build. In low and even mid magic environments they shine.
Bards, clerics, druids, wizards and even rangers and paladins - they all do it to some extent. (Yes, you can do it with sorcerers too)
Or perhaps the key word is "rely on", meaning you can accept it to a minor degree as in rangers, paladins and minor class casters?
Rogue is a very versatile and self reliant build type. It gets even better when combined with wizard or a fighter type class.
Bard is the epitome of versatility and the class can be multiclassed  with great success.
Shadowdancer with HIPS adds a great means of crowd control to stealth characters.
Cleric is a power class (almost) unparallelled. Quote by Unknown:" If you are afraid of dying, play a cleric!"
We have already talked about some of the powers of the Druid class.
Wizard with the access to all arcane spells is very versatile with utility spells, buffs and attack spells. All the buffs even let you play them as melee characters.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: There is the classic Fighter / Bard / RDD, and if you would allow self-buffing, Cleric / Bard / RDD.

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote:Agadris, I wonder why you will exclude self buffers when you ask for a versatile build. In low and even mid magic environments they shine.
Bards, clerics, druids, wizards and even rangers and paladins - they all do it to some extent. (Yes, you can do it with sorcerers too)
Or perhaps the key word is "rely on", meaning you can accept it to a minor degree as in rangers, paladins and minor class casters?
Rogue is a very versatile and self reliant build type. It gets even better when combined with wizard or a fighter type class.
Bard is the epitome of versatility and the class can be multiclassed  with great success.
Shadowdancer with HIPS adds a great means of crowd control to stealth characters.
Cleric is a power class (almost) unparallelled. Quote by Unknown:" If you are afraid of dying, play a cleric!"
We have already talked about some of the powers of the Druid class.
Wizard with the access to all arcane spells is very versatile with utility spells, buffs and attack spells. All the buffs even let you play them as melee characters.
Mick, I'm not excluding them per se. It was merely a suggestion on how to make the challenge of finding a build that can pull itself by the bootstraps (i.e. survive relying only on everything that comes out of level progression and feats) a bit more challenging.
I just thought that buffs could be left out because they, at the end of the day, are dispellable. Still, every self-buffer is a welcome addition to the thread.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Some modules and persistent worlds will have a 'rod of fast buffing'
Its a godsend for those self-buffers.
RE dispellability a close to pure spell caster build will rarely get their buffs removed beyond caster level 24, with the exception of breaches and Mord's

If we include self-buffers in a no magic mundane only item environment I think cleric will win every time. 
Take trickery domain for invisibility/improved invisibility
Other domain could be travel cast extended haste on one's self for example.
Have a caster level of 35, we are talking about 70 rounds of haste.
Add in buffs like extended divine power extended divine favor, aid, bless, bulls strength, magic vestment you're laughing
The remaining 5 levels could be anything you like. Rogue / Shadowdancer / Fighter / Monk are good choices for light multiclassing

I think a build like the Abjurant Champion (the-abjurant-champion-wizard-26-ftr-6-c ... .html#p742) would also be pretty sweet too. I'm not a master at all of the wizard class, but any build with a AB close to 40 with an undispellable full wizard spell book plus epic spells EMA and Epic Warding gets a vote from me

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
No! Bloody no! And then some more no with a big fat lump of no on top! Do not let these sneaky arcanist (Wiz/Sorc) types or religious zealots (Cleric/Druid) turn your head with their sweet inveiglings, Agadris! I can just about allow Bard - but only for the Song. The rest can "get thee hence!"

In his unassuming way, Empyre neglects to mention his own stupendous series of Order of the Wyrm builds - many and varied in focus, but all Monk 25/ Sorc 1/ RDD 14, which are always worth consideration. Yes, I know there's a level of Sorcerer in there, but it's useless and only there to access RDD goodies, so stop whining, you lot! It's the first build I take anywhere, and it works. And what's not to like about a build that doesn't die and just keeps getting stronger?

Sorry, rant over...for now

posts.content:

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:Do you really want me to answer that first line?
Can't imagine where you got the second line from, but let's assume you're right...
Third line - you've met me, I don't do Monk cheese.
Fourth line (rather depends on whether you've seen "The Big Bang Theory", I suspect) - Spock!
And finally, I'll give it my best shot. See if I'm really ready to be an Epic Character Builder yet.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I like cheese. Its a good topping for certain dishes and has good nutritional value.

Its certainly a common addition on the menu at the Epic Character Builders.

Some of the ECB best chefs use it as an ingredient in almost all their dishes.

I'm sure your doctor has advised you at some stage it is important to have a varied and well balanced diet to maintain one's wellbeing.

I'm also sure your mother has also told you its important to have your vegetables even if it includes some 'over-powering' flavours

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
You can eat cheese without eating real cheese.
Some sort of a diet cheese would do perhaps, perhaps not.
You can become a mage without being one & I'm not referring to umd of course,
You can be a Rak instead & run around spamming Ice Storms, unfortunately, they do little else, looks kinda like this:
Ice Storm, Ice Storm, Ice Storm,....Ice Storm!

posts.content:

Its certainly a common addition on the menu at the Epic Character Builders.

I'm also sure your mother has also told you its important to have your vegetables even if it includes some 'over-powering' flavours
It seems I'm going to have to do line by line again...
1. So's bacon.
2. And?
3. Yes, and they're dishes I don't use.
4. Indeed - and part of that advice was to have less cheese.
5. Entirely too many possible responses here - none of which will help my profile shine any brighter.
Still, thanks for the support.

EDIT: Good here, innit?

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Sorry stag was hoping you found it amusing

Didn't mean to offend if I did

Some players find choosing the most powerful choices possible spoils enjoyable

Others want the challenge of less powerful choices and enjoy achieving victory 'despite all odds'

I think this is a slow maturation process - once you have tried out the uber builds, one will gravitate to other builds which have their own enjoyment factors

And there is nothing more enjoyable than winning with an 'underdog' build through tactical knowledge and skillful play

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Orion2019 wrote:.
You may have hit upon something important here (I'm talking in build terms, not existentially). I know I started without playing any uber-builds and am building up to them (see what I did there?), rather than going the other way. To a certain extent that would explain my differences with Max and failure to adequately play his builds. I always liked playable at all levels rather than anything else. I believe it helps you develop incrementally, so you get better at different play-styles on your way. Others have a different view, which is fine.
Cheers

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Heh, now you made me remember another good one with him...
When he returned a couple of years ago & start posting that experience had changed him & he wanted to revise his builds so that they are more playable...

I thought he was a doppelganger of shorts & I have to see one from Durlag's Tower!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote:Heh, now you made me remember another good one with him...
When he returned a couple of years ago & start posting that experience had changed him & he wanted to revise his builds so that they are more playable...

I thought he was a doppelganger of shorts & I have to see one from Durlag's Tower!
Ooh, now you say it, I remember! I know he's going to be away for a good while yet, but I'll be chasing him about that!
And now you've got me thinking about Durlag's Tower - what was the first son's name - it began with a K - had the cursed helm and the Dwarven Doomguards looking after his tomb?

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Always pays to check, humor can be a double edged sword

Fascinating you go the other way, I always viewed a uber build as a 'leg up' so to speak, later on one can take on the challenges of the 'pure fighter' build and the 80hp con 6 elven sorceress. 

If you can overcome the challenges of the harder builds and succeed then uber builds would get boring

That being said when you come home, your brain is fried from a tough day, sometimes you just need to point and click and an uber build just does that for you really

Looks like my brain needs some cooling :)

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I don't remember who, but somebody who knows WoG well said that my Order of the Wyrm builds would not do well there.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I'm not sure I agree with whoever said that,

If this is the build (order-of-the-wyrm-17-monk-25-sorcerer-1 ... 15525.html)

base AB 40 with ITWF kamas with Monk UBAB, 9 attacks / round, able to use arcane scrolls through sorcerer (ie tensors / improved invisibility / flame weapon / keen weapon), devastating critical, untouchable spell resistance, mind immunity, improved evasion, great saves...

One should be able to get through massive portions of the persistent world solo

Perhaps it was in comparison with a high magic world which had uber Kamas or something like that?

posts.author: Agadris
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:No! Bloody no! And then some more no with a big fat lump of no on top! Do not let these sneaky arcanist (Wiz/Sorc) types or religious zealots (Cleric/Druid) turn your head with their sweet inveiglings, Agadris! I can just about allow Bard - but only for the Song. In his unassuming way, Empyre neglects to mention his own stupendous series of Order of the Wyrm builds - many and varied in focus, but all Monk 25/ Sorc 1/ RDD 14, which are always worth consideration. Yes, I know there's a level of Sorcerer in there, but it's useless and only there to access RDD goodies, so stop whining, you lot! It's the first build I take anywhere, and it works. And what's not to like about a build that doesn't die and just keeps getting stronger?

Sorry, rant over...for now
Stag, incidentally, I used to play pure casters back in the day - due to my fascination with magic-wielders in any fantasy pieces - going for the highest DC-s possible and, much later, opting for a Melee Mage play-style. 
Sometimes I would add a bit of Rogue because OC and many modules simply demand that you have trap and lock-picking skills or a dedicated rogue at your side (and bloody "I AM A HAWFLEEN THEEF, AH AM AH AM" of the infamous Tommy Undergallows just didn't cut it for me). I guess, that's where my eternal desire to have a character who can take care of nearly everything comes from, it was learnt through many hours of disabling traps and picking locks.
As to the Bards, they are great, but I really wish there were the feat from 3.5 rules that allows them to cast spells with no penalties if wearing light armor.

posts.content:

Ahh... I wish there were a mod that would add this rod into any module you wanted
And speaking of high-AB spellswords, they are great, indeed. However, there's one thing I don't like about them (some of them) and it's just my opinion, of course... most of them focus heavily on melee classes pre-epic and most of your playthrough you play as if your character were a purely melee-type. Then you start casting some spells at the epic stage AND... the module is usually over.
Now, I know, that playing on PWs is different but if you are not into playing on-line...

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:I don't remember who, but somebody who knows WoG well said that my Order of the Wyrm builds would not do well there.
That was Max (surprise, surprise), and it was in either the discussion of  my Farmer build or in the MTS thread. I didn't - and don't - believe him for a second. After all, much of the time it's about how you play a build as well as the build itself, and that means getting to know it - it's like driving: if you don't know how to drive you're as likely to crash a Ferrari as you are a Skoda.
For the record, I still use the Order of the Wyrm builds you gave me back in December 2014 in my second ever build request, and would happily stand by them anywhere.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:So... a first-ever caster build by a true melee-lobbyist Stagmeister is coming then, right?
Certainly not! Tried it, didn't like it - it chafed all over: Shh - Tell No One
No, this is about coming up with an ultimate slayer of casters.
So we need an 'Anti-Mage'!
Monk 20+ is great for untouchable spell resistance, mind immunity, monk speed, improved evasion and improved knockdown
Then we need to figure out where to go from there.
Perhaps Dwarf for +2 to saves against spells
Devastating critical would be nice, turn that instant death ability that mages have against them, and with their low fortitude save... SPLAT
Sneak or death attack as well. Knock em down, 6d6 sneak attack 6-7 times per round, good night.
If Stag can tolerate it, UMD, but only to use Mord's and Breaches to remove enemy buffs, all other usages are forbidden by the mage hunter code.
Then add some full BAB class to access the BAB 26+, perhaps CoT or Fighter. 
Or shadowdancer for HiPS but in Vanilla NWN its pretty hard countered by True Sight spells, I take it?

Oi - this is my challenge from Captain Stabby! (Helpful and constructive as your contribution is, Orion, so thank you.)
My initial thought, btw, was Monk (no great surprise there) - and I'm still trying to locate Valerfor's Grand Master of Flowers (or Blossom, as I like to call him) for reference. My second thought, perhaps counter-intuitively, was an Arcane Archer (without making any actual use of spells, of course), and that's still taking shape. Then there's Dwarven Defender to consider, and a dedicated trap-smith, and all manner of other stuff.
I'm just letting it mull for now, but I'll keep you posted.
Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Just for information, I've now tracked down Valerfor's Grand Master of Flowers - oddly enough in a thread titled "Looking for a Mage-Killer" - and the discussion also mentions AAs. It's all gone very weird. Nothing new in this world, eh?

Mage-Killer

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
For something very aggressive I suggest: Monk 26/ Ftr 4/ CoT 10,
Half-Orc: Str 19(36), Dex 14, Con 10, Int 9, Wis 14, Cha 6
BAB: 26
AB: 43/ 40/ 37/ 34/ 31/ 28 (Fists of Death)
DMG: 1D20 +19/ 19-20 X2 & Dev Crit DC: 43(49)
SR: 38 (Cannot be reduced)
2/Day Etherealness (Cannot be dispelled) X26 rounds each.
AC: 29 (naked)
Very min/maxed but I wanted to see its highest potential here, if you went Kamas, then I would also suggest having UMD.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:Just for information, I've now tracked down Valerfor's Grand Master of Flowers - oddly enough in a thread titled "Looking for a Mage-Killer" - and the discussion also mentions AAs. It's all gone very weird. Nothing new in this world, eh?

Mage-Killer
Task accomplished!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Maybe try a Bard / RDD / AA with ranged Dev Crit, so the reciprocating damage spells won't hurt you.  However, then you lose the Monk saves and spell resistance.  I have one optimized for Aielund, one for SoF, and one for MTS.  I could post any or all of those here, but will do so only if you ask me to, because it is your challenge.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:Maybe try a Bard / RDD / AA with ranged Dev Crit, so the reciprocating damage spells won't hurt you.  However, then you lose the Monk saves and spell resistance.  I have one optimized for Aielund, one for SoF, and one for MTS.  I could post any or all of those here, but will do so only if you ask me to, because it is your challenge.
Well, as Mick informs me, my task is already accomplished (so it transpires it was one of research and memory, rather than one of building, which is a relief in many ways), so let the floodgates open! I'd be really interested to see as many of these Bard/RDD/AA builds as you feel like sharing, thanks!

Edit: made an adjustment to sneak Called Shot in the build without sacrificing any AB
Edit 2: Added Blind Fight and Armor Skin to the build as suggested
Edit 3: Feats rearranged as suggested

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
You miss, Blind-Fight, Armor Skin & Epic Prowess, Orion.
Unless I haven't drunk enough coffee yet, & I know I don't ...

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Mmmm I can drop two great dexes for that

I re-did the build as you were typing to add Epic Prowess

I read heaps from forums and stuff some people wrote blind fight wasn't needed for archers but I didn't quite understand why

Doesn't anyone know why blind fight wouldn't be needed for an archer?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Beutiful, now move BF back pre-epic & the PA feats one slot after that, it won't affect anything because you take OC/DC after that anyway.
And many will say many things but always trust your gut, you're firing into melee, why BF shouldn't be essential? You want to miss as few attacks as possible!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I agree, its in!

Thanks for the very rapid feedback man. Very much appreciated.

Not sure when I can take this baby for a spin it looks like I have a few builds to play...

But a ranged dev critter with UMD and base AB 52... I get the feeling that build has to be played sooner rather than later...

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: It's like having a stable full of stallions, ready to charge!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content: I could also put that last Bard level to 37 rather than 40 to get the tumble and UMD dumps earlier but I'll fix that up later, getting coffee myself

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Solid move, & since you went the trouble of going back & forth & polishing this, the numbers & playability both are good, I suggest putting it in its rightful place amongst the other forty-level builds, don't let it wander here aimlessly, it might catch a cold.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I think that is reasonable. 

I just had a look at the Bard/RDD/AA builds in the ECB Archives and what I could find in our forum (through google search site:https://www.tapatalk.com/groups/nwnecbguild/ "arcane archer") and it seems sufficiently unique to others to post in the finalised build section. 

I'll reference the other builds I found for comparison.

Thanks for helping me out Valerfor

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I had already done the work for you (without you knowing), that's why I told you to "seal the deal".

And helping each other is a given man, I want to see the apprentice outgrowing the master.

The only thing that neither myself nor you nor Mick is gonna accomplish here, is to make Stag play a sorceress, other than that, the sky is the limit!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: I hope he's sleeping now & don't see that last sentence, I'm not ready yet for a fight...

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Kalistez wrote:I reckon Stag would look pretty sexy in some low cut Sorceress robes !
Hahaha!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote:Empyre, you need rapid-shot in there man, do something & get it, please.
To get Rapid Shot, I would have to give up either Blind Fight, Epic Prowess, or Armor Skin.  Losing any one of those would be a high price, but everything else is crucial to the build.  The Aielund version, which doesn't have Dev Crit, does have Rapid Shot.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I'll have you all know I have a very nice little off-the-shoulder Robe of Vecna stashed away somewhere. The problem is that an ogre in a frock is still an ogre (need to work on some self-image issues. I know I hide it well, but I weep at night. So thanks for bringing it up.

EDIT: Oh, and a couple (well, three) more Minsc-isms for you:
"Evil - meet my sword. Sword - MEET EVIL!"
"Hear that, Evil? Minsc has a new witch! Woe is you!"
"What you need is a swift kick in the evils."

posts.author: Kalistez
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:I'll have you all know I have a very nice little off-the-shoulder Robe of Vecna stashed away somewhere. The problem is that an ogre in a frock is still an ogre (need to work on some self-image issues. I know I hide it well, but I weep at night. So thanks for bringing it up.
"What you need is a swift kick in the evils."
I'm assuming this quote is meant for me ?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: On your second point - no, not at all! It's just a remembered Minsc-ism. But it's interesting that you think it might...Hmm...

posts.author: Kalistez
posts.content:
Yes...
Very strange !

posts.author: Orion
posts.content: https://baldursgate.fandom.com/wiki/Det ... l_(priest)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Thanks, Orion, It is, of course, an absolutely rubbish spell/ability. You get to know there are bad dudes around - well, no shit, Sherlock! (Pardon my language, please). And it's even worse in re-spawning areas. In BG1, in the Firewine Ruins, I guarantee you'll detect over 50 kobold commandos. Then another 50. And so on ad infinitum. And it doesn't tell you where they actually are - just "around". Very bloody helpful. Possibly the most pointless ability ever.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Would it be useful in towns, where evil hides amongst the innocent I wonder?
Or to solve certain quests?
It has been about a decade since I played that game

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
The usefulness of this special ability comes into play in PnP.
It's main purpose for the Paladin, is to make sure that the opposition is evil & he doesn't waste his "smite evil" attempt.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Orion2019 wrote:Would it be useful in towns, where evil hides amongst the innocent I wonder?
Or to solve certain quests?
It has been about a decade since I played that game
Nope.
As the expression has it: about as much use as a chocolate fireguard.
On a nicer Minsc quote: "Ooh, squirrels! Throw nuts, Boo!"

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Agadris wrote: Stag, incidentally, I used to play pure casters back in the day - due to my fascination with magic-wielders in any fantasy pieces - going for the highest DC-s possible and, much later, opting for a Melee Mage play-style.
Sometimes I would add a bit of Rogue because OC and many modules simply demand that you have trap and lock-picking skills or a dedicated rogue at your side (and bloody "I AM A HAWFLEEN THEEF, AH AM AH AM" of the infamous Tommy Undergallows just didn't cut it for me). I guess, that's where my eternal desire to have a character who can take care of nearly everything comes from, it was learnt through many hours of disabling traps and picking locks.
As to the Bards, they are great, but I really wish there were the feat from 3.5 rules that allows them to cast spells with no penalties if wearing light armor.
Now I understand where you're coming from and what sparked this request.
Maybe the answer is to play multiclassed rogue type characters with UMD, traps, stealth, HIPS, high AB and plenty of SA damage, skills galore etc.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:
Empyre65 wrote:I don't remember who, but somebody who knows WoG well said that my Order of the Wyrm builds would not do well there.
That was Max (surprise, surprise), and it was in either the discussion of  my Farmer build or in the MTS thread. I didn't - and don't - believe him for a second. After all, much of the time it's about how you play a build as well as the build itself, and that means getting to know it - it's like driving: if you don't know how to drive you're as likely to crash a Ferrari as you are a Skoda.
For the record, I still use the Order of the Wyrm builds you gave me back in December 2014 in my second ever build request, and would happily stand by them anywhere.
Hi Empyre and Stag!
You will be pleased to know I saw a player 2 days ago on World of Greyhawk with a Monk 14 / Sorcerer 1 / Red Dragon Disciple 10 build. 
I have no doubt that must be an Order of the Wyrm build running around!
So to get to level 25 this guy must have done well, and as such your build as done well on WoG. 
So real living and breathing evidence right there!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
That reminds me that Empyre was about to start playing WoG offline as his next project but we have no news about it since then.

I guess "Doom" claimed him back for some time.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: There are some projects for Doom that I am working on that I want to finish so I could then return my focus to NWN.  I did get a start in single-player WoG, though.  I read everything there is to read in the starting room, including that library in the corner, then I entered Homlet, which I have explored, looking for quests.  The only quest I have found so far is the Temple of Elemental Evil quest, which I think is not the very first quest I should start with.  I have not yet left the village, and I don't know which exit to take.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Search for a Druid near the road. There is a path through the woods nearby, that leads to the Moathouse, that should be your first "dungeon".

Btw, the original Doom had a new record recently, it still amazes me to see people dedicated to it after more than 25 years.
